author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Katie Rogers and Reid J. Epstein
title: Inside the Trump-Harris Debate Prep: Method Acting, Insults, Tough Questions
description: Kamala Harris is camped out at a Pittsburgh hotel. Donald Trump is being peppered informally by aides. Both sides share the same belief about why the debate is so crucial.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris is holed up for five days in a Pittsburgh hotel, doing highly choreographed debate practice sessions ahead of Tuesday night’s clash. There’s a stage and replica TV lighting and an adviser in full Lee Strasberg method-acting mode, not just playing Donald J. Trump but inhabiting him, wearing a boxy suit and a long tie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Room Next Door’ Claims Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
description: The film, starring Tilda Swinton and Julianne Moore, is the director Pedro Almodóvar’s English-language debut.
content: “The Room Next Door,” directed by Pedro Almodóvar, was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 81st Venice International Film Festival on Saturday by a competition jury led by Isabelle Huppert. In the film, a journalist with cancer (Tilda Swinton) asks an old friend, played by Julianne Moore, to stay with her when she decides to take her own life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Harris’s Combative Debate Style Will Get Its Biggest Test Against Trump
description: Kamala Harris’s razor-sharp debate skills have powered her political ascent. Her success next week will turn on how well she adapts to an unpredictable rival.
content: Few of the people gathered in the San Francisco church knew quite what to expect from Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Flatley
title: Art Museum Etiquette for Dummies (and Overthinkers)
description: An illustrated guide to seeing a blockbuster exhibition like Hiroshige at the Brooklyn Museum. For starters, don’t go on opening day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Night of the Supermodels in New York, Guest Appearance by Rihanna
description: What happened when Pieter Mulier brought the Alaïa show to the Guggenheim.
content: It takes a lot to distract from Rihanna. Especially when she enters a room wearing a cleavage-spilling corset underneath a cream net gown with hundreds of seed pearls caught in its web, sits next to Liv Tyler and starts whispering in her ear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Finger Food for Dinner
description: Think Mexican hot dogs, peel and eat shrimp and milk bread rolls.
content: Hi everyone, me again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Spy Chiefs of the C.I.A. and MI6 Convene, on a Couch and for a Crowd
description: Appearing together publicly for the first time in the history of their agencies, the heads of the U.S. and British intelligence services discussed Ukraine’s incursion into Russia and the war in Gaza.
content: The chiefs of the C.I.A. and the British Secret Intelligence Service, appearing together publicly for the first time in the history of their agencies, said on Saturday in London that Ukraine’s surprise offensive in the Kursk region had exposed vulnerabilities in Russia’s military and was an “audacious” effort to “try and change the game” in the two-and-a-half-year-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: New Images of Mercury Show Speckled Surface in Sharp Detail
description: BepiColombo, a joint European-Japanese mission, completed its latest flyby of Mercury, sending back a sneak peek of the cratered planet it will begin to orbit in 2026.
content: On Thursday, a spacecraft operated by the European Space Agency and Japan made its closest approach yet to Mercury, sending back sharp, black-and-white images of the planet’s barren, speckled surface at sunrise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian Forces Block Russian Advance on a Key Eastern Town
description: Russia’s drive toward Pokrovsk has stalled along one part of the frontline, but its troops continue to advance in other parts of eastern Ukraine, and its long-range aerial attacks continue.
content: Reinforced Ukrainian defenders in a key location on the front have halted what had been relentless Russian advances in eastern Ukraine, according to soldiers and battlefield maps. But Russia continued to advance elsewhere, and pressed on Saturday with long-range bombardment of more distant cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Jacey Fortin
title: Georgia Tests a Novel Tactic in School Shootings: Putting Parents on Trial
description: After four people were killed at Apalachee High School, prosecutors charged a student and his father, who officials say had given the boy the gun as a gift.
content: In a landmark criminal case in Michigan earlier this year, James and Jennifer Crumbley became the first parents convicted in connection with killings carried out by their child in a mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Crowley
title: Iran Sent Short-Range Missiles to Russia, Western Officials Say
description: U.S. and European countries had warned of sanctions if Iran provided weapons that could be used against Ukraine. President Biden’s lame-duck status could hamper a response.
content: Iran has sent short-range ballistic missiles to Russia, according to U.S. and European officials, despite sharp warnings from Washington and its allies not to provide those armaments to Moscow to use against targets in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
title: Once, Catholic Priests Came to Indonesia. Now, It Exports Them.
description: A seminary on Flores, a Catholic-majority island in Indonesia, ordains so many priests that a lot of them go abroad to serve the faithful.
content: On an Indonesian island about 500 miles east of Bali, an open-air truck traversed up winding roads one recent Sunday. It was taking dozens of jovial men, some already in white robes, and their songbooks and guitars to the church on top of the hill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 7, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 7, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about the prospect of an early election in Canada after a left-leaning party withdrew its support for the Liberal Party of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau misstated the date by which a new election must be held. Under the Constitution, a new election must be held before October 2026, not October 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books Celebrating Happy Marriages
description: Elizabeth Alexander and John Bayley loved their partners to the end.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Lola Fadulu
title: Queens Is Abuzz Over Two Americans in the U.S. Open Finals
description: For the first time in more than two decades, an American man and an American woman will play in the U.S. Open singles finals.
content: Outside Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday night, dozens of tennis fans gathered, looking up at a screen broadcasting the match inside, the all-American men’s semifinal between Frances Tiafoe and Taylor Fritz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: In Threatened Island Nation, Pope Hears Plea for Climate Action
description: Pope Francis is visiting Papua New Guinea, which has been exploited for its natural resources and is imperiled by rising sea levels.
content: In the Pacific island nation of Papua New Guinea, hundreds of people may soon have to abandon their homes, pushed inland by the rising sea. Hundreds more were buried in a devastating landslide this year. Around the country, intensive logging is shrinking the island’s lush rainforests, and mine tailings have polluted its rivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Klinenberg
title: The Killer Climate Disaster That Has No Name
description: Heat waves are America’s deadliest weather events. It’s time we name them.
content: Do you remember the heat dome that settled over Washington and Oregon in 2021, leading to thousands of hospitalizations and over 600 estimated fatalities? Or last summer’s heat wave in Phoenix, when the temperature hit or exceeded 110 degrees for 31 straight days, accounting for most of Maricopa County’s 645 heat-related deaths in 2023?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What Is That Song in ‘Beetlejuice Beetlejuice’?
description: Meet the new “Day-O”: Richard Harris’s 1968 psychedelic pop hit “MacArthur Park,” which Donna Summer remade as a disco anthem.
content: Some spoilers follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Pivotal Decision That Led to a Resurgence of Polio
description: In 2016, the global health authorities removed a type of poliovirus from the oral vaccine. The virus caused a growing number of outbreaks and has now arrived in Gaza.
content: The poliovirus that paralyzed a child in Gaza, the first case in the region in 25 years, has traveled a long path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Harrison
title: When a Smart House Turns Evil
description: In Mason Coile’s new horror novel, “William,” an intelligent robot begins to lead its feckless creator to terrible places in the name of “freedom.”
content: To create an almost human is to create a monster. So speculative writers have suggested since Mary Shelley. The advent of artificial intelligence has only given this gothic dread fresh urgency. Haunted by the question of whether consciousness can be trapped on a circuit board, we seem incapable of inventing machines in our own image without imagining those machines attacking us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Donahue
title: High Schoolers Need to Do Less So That They Can Do Better
description: We need to let students slow down. Critical cognition, by definition, takes time.
content: To earn the distinction of valedictorian at Sunny Hills High School in Fullerton, Calif., a student must maintain a straight-A average and take at least 32 honors-level, semester-long classes. One weak “Gatsby” essay during these four years, one math test taken after an ankle sprain, one poorly conjugated verb can put a leak in the boat. And yet this past May, 39 of the 606 graduating seniors maintained the buoyancy to become valedictorians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Adam Satariano, Aaron Krolik and Steven Lee Myers
title: How Telegram Became a Playground for Criminals, Extremists and Terrorists
description: Drug dealers, scammers and white nationalists openly conduct business and spread toxic speech on the platform, according to a Times analysis of more than 3.2 million Telegram messages.
content: Telegram has become a global sewer of criminal activity, disinformation, child sexual abuse material, terrorism and racist incitement, according to a four-month investigation by The New York Times that analyzed more than 3.2 million Telegram messages from over 16,000 channels. The company, which offers features that enable criminals, terrorists and grifters to organize at scale and to sidestep scrutiny from the authorities, has looked the other way as illegal and extremist activities have flourished openly on the app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: 3 Die Amid Outbreak of Legionnaires’ Disease at an Assisted Living Home
description: Twenty-five people connected to the home, in Albany, N.Y., have been hospitalized amid the outbreak, officials said.
content: Three people who tested positive for Legionnaires’ disease have died amid an outbreak at an assisted living home in Albany, N.Y., that sickened at least seven others, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Online Credit Unions Offering High Interest Rates on Savings May Be Fakes
description: Ontario’s financial regulator has issued warnings about three websites illegally claiming to be credit unions, but it is powerless to close them.
content: The dazzling white lobby of the office tower at 99 Bank Street in Ottawa certainly looks like a place where you’d find the headquarters of a financial institution. But up on the floor that Ottawa Credit Union’s elaborate website lists as the location of the company’s head office, there’s only a federal government agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon and Sean Keenan
title: Georgia Suspect’s Family Faced Eviction and Other Turmoil Before Shooting
description: Court and law enforcement records lay out the turbulence in the teenager’s family in recent years.
content: The 14-year-old accused of killing four people at his Georgia high school this week had switched middle schools and drawn the attention of authorities who suspected he had posted school shooting threats online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Ken Bensinger and Jim Rutenberg
title: Russia Secretly Worms Its Way Into America’s Conservative Media
description: Federal prosecutors say Russia paid an American media company to push pro-Kremlin messages from social media influencers including Benny Johnson, Tim Pool and Dave Rubin.
content: In early 2022, a young couple from Canada, Lauren Chen and Liam Donovan, registered a new company in Tennessee that went on to create a social media outlet called Tenet Media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Underwear for Horses? A Hoax, Cemented in Print.
description: Alan Abel duped the nation — and The New York Times — with his satirical nonprofit, the Society for Indecency to Naked Animals. Artifacts in The Times’s archives serve as embarrassing reminders.
content: When Alan Abel died in 2018 at age 94, The New York Times took extra care to confirm that he had actually died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: How Do You Know if Your Apartment Is (or Should Be) Rent-Stabilized?
description: When a new owner takes over a rental building, there can be confusion about the status of the units inside.
content: Q: I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper West Side for more than 12 years. Among the 48 units here, six are currently unoccupied due to liens on the building, incurred because of massive maintenance violations. Last month, the owner sold it to a limited liability company, and a management company has taken over. Now, some tenants are receiving rent invoices at market rates. Should the rents have been raised? The management company has requested our social security numbers and copies of our leases. Do we have to provide this? Shouldn’t the old landlord have handed over our leases?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Street Artist Documents War in Ukraine, One Stark Mural at a Time
description: Using ruins as his canvas, Gamlet Zinkivskyi has captured life in wartime Ukraine in dozens of grim, gripping and harshly beautiful paintings. “Broken, but invincible,” read one captioned work.
content: As Ukrainian troops began to push the Russians back from the outskirts of the city of Kharkiv in May 2022, Gamlet Zinkivskyi, a street artist who knows how to shoot as well as paint, was eager to fight for his hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Making End-of-Life Decisions
description: Readers discuss unwanted medical care and choosing to die.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: I Love the Kids in My Life. And I’m Raising None of Them.
description: You don’t have to have kids to have kids in your life.
content: Recently, a book tour gave me the opportunity to travel around America. Budgets being what they are, I primarily chose cities where I had friends who would happily provide me with places to stay. These were homes, almost without exception, filled with children. I have no children of my own, and this felt like a serendipitous chance to catch up with many of the kids in my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 455
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 8, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Hillary Clinton Has Advice on Debating Trump: ‘He Can Be Rattled’
description: The 2016 Democratic nominee fell short to Donald Trump, but she had strong debate moments against him. In an interview, she offered some thoughts for Kamala Harris.
content: Hillary Clinton has as much experience as any Democrat in debating Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: At the U.S. Open, Hourly-Wage Ushers Corral the Well-Heeled Crowds
description: Since fans often must wait until breaks between games to enter, employees in blue shirts have the dicey task of holding them back for several excruciating minutes until play is paused.
content: Arriving late to Arthur Ashe Stadium, four cocktail-cradling fans waltzed toward their courtside U.S. Open seats like it was an extended happy hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Lloyd Ziff, Visionary Photographer and Art Director, Dies at 81
description: He designed some of the most visually exciting magazines of the 1970s and ’80s. But his real love, and eventually his focus, was photography.
content: Lloyd Ziff was not yet a celebrated art director in 1968, when he photographed an art school classmate, Robert Mapplethorpe, and his girlfriend, Patti Smith, in their tiny Brooklyn apartment. “I found them very beautiful,” Mr. Ziff said years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small and Mark Sommerfeld
title: Nicole Eisenman at the Tipping Point
description: As the artist prepares for a major exhibition in Madison Square Park, Eisenman takes stock of the winding path to fame. What is gained and what is lost when your art is political?
content: In the basement of an old museum, the artist Nicole Eisenman grabbed a cordless hacksaw and started demolishing the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Mr. Greedy, Father to Many African Penguins at Maryland Zoo, Dies at 33
description: An African penguin who left many offspring in his long life, he belonged to the largest colony of the aquatic bird species in North America, according to the zoo.
content: The popular African penguin known as Mr. Greedy, a fixture of the Maryland Zoo who had sired many offspring and left “an astounding 230 descendants” over five generations, has died after an age-related decline in his health, the zoo said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: What We Know About the Investigations Involving Eric Adams’s Top Aides
description: The administration of New York City’s mayor was thrown into turmoil as federal inquiries reached his inner circle.
content: When federal agents seized the phones of some of New York City’s highest-ranking officials this week, the administration of Mayor Eric Adams, already reeling from other legal problems, was further destabilized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: If a Threat Is Not a Crime, Can the Police Prevent a School Shooting?
description: Officers are limited in their response to a possible threat of violence, but they are being trained to identify and monitor worrisome behavior earlier.
content: Last year, when an investigator from the sheriff’s office in Jackson County, Ga., interviewed a 13-year-old and his father about a possible online threat to “shoot up a middle school,” the teen denied responsibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Out of a Horror Movie:’ Typhoon Yagi Makes Landfall in Vietnam
description: At least four people have died and thousands were evacuated after Yagi, one of the strongest storms to hit northern Vietnam, brought powerful winds and torrential rains.
content: Typhoon Yagi made landfall in Vietnam on Saturday, packing powerful winds and torrential rain that killed at least four people and injured more than 70 people, according to state-run media, and forced tens of thousands to evacuate. Earlier, the storm smashed into southern China, where at least three people died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,177
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, September 8, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: In California, Controlled Fires Can Save Homes. Why Aren’t More Happening?
description: Experts say these intentional burns reduce the risk of wildfires and more should be done. But real barriers remain.
content: A few days after the Park fire tore through Cohasset, a small forest community in Northern California, in late July, Dallas Koller drove out to inspect the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Forget the Yacht. The Best Travel Is on Foot, Through Wilderness.
description: On our public lands, nobody can pull rank on you. Except a bear.
content: Some folks think the best way to travel is by private jet. Or yacht. My choice: by foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Change Can Be Beautiful. Just Ask Will and Harper.
description: The superstar comedian and his best friend and collaborator discuss the journey that deepened their friendship.
content: How well do we know our friends? Our neighbors? Ourselves? In the new documentary “Will & Harper,” which opens in select theaters on Sept. 13 and will stream on Netflix starting Sept. 27, the superstar comedian Will Ferrell and his best friend and frequent collaborator, Harper Steele, take a New York-to-California road trip together to try to answer those questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Tony Blair’s Advice to Rookie Leaders: Tend to Your Legacy Before It’s Too Late
description: In an interview, the former British prime minister discussed his new book ‘On Leadership,’ the dysfunction of U.S. politics, and deflected questions about Elon Musk’s influence.
content: Tony Blair is out with a new book, “On Leadership,” which he says offers all the tips he wished he’d been told when he entered 10 Downing Street in 1997.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Frannie Carr Toth, Wendy Dorr, Jon Pareles and Pat McCusker
title: Around the World in 36 Minutes With Laurie Anderson
description: Her new album brings Amelia Earhart’s tragic final flight to life.
content: The eternally innovative performance artist Laurie Anderson is out with a new album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Tristan Spinski
title: Shocked by Extreme Storms, a Maine Fishing Town Fights to Save Its Waterfront
description: After two devastating storms hit Stonington in January, plans are multiplying to raise and fortify wharves, roads and buildings. But will that be enough?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Broken Again. A National Advocate for Drug Recovery Relapses.
description: William Cope Moyers told the world he had it all figured out after beating his addiction to crack cocaine. But then a dentist gave him an opioid pain killer.
content: In “Broken,” a memoir published in 2006, William Cope Moyers wrote of his near fatal addiction to crack cocaine and his hard-fought recovery. The book proved to be a humble celebration about the potential for rehabilitation, and Mr. Moyers became a national champion for treatment and recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: An Action Prince and Titular Cat
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 7, 2024.
content: “Maybe it’s weird, but I’ll need to be barefoot on the stage. I’ll need to place my hand on the floor of the stage and on the set to feel connected.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israel Strikes Schools Turned Shelters in Gaza
description: Israel said it had launched a “precise strike” against Hamas militants operating from two school compounds in northern Gaza, as the family of a slain American lashes out at Israel.
content: The Israeli military said on Saturday that it had struck two school compounds in northern Gaza that Hamas was using as a military base, while the family of a young Turkish American woman released an angry statement blaming Israel for her killing in a West Bank protest on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders and Orlando Mayorquín
title: Five People Injured in Kentucky Highway Shooting, Officials Say
description: Nine vehicles were damaged by gunfire on I-75, the authorities said. The victims were in stable condition and a search for a suspect was underway.
content: The authorities in Kentucky were looking on Sunday morning for a suspect in connection with a shooting on an interstate highway that left at least five people seriously injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Family Inheritance?
description: The plot thickens in this themeless puzzle by David P. Williams, the fifth in a series.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David P. Williams’s fifth crossword for The New York Times; all have been themeless, each with a challenging 66 entries. The puzzles have identical geometry and are all inspired by a poem by Wallace Stevens called “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.” Are you intrigued? I figure I’ll start including links to his past puzzles with every coming installment — one, two, three and four — in case anyone wants to look for a pattern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Texas Sues for Access to Records of Women Seeking Out-of-State Abortions
description: The lawsuit takes aim at federal privacy rules, including one enacted this year that Ken Paxton, the state attorney general, called “a backdoor attempt at weakening Texas’ laws.”
content: Texas has sued to block federal rules that prohibit investigators from viewing the medical records of women who travel out of state to seek abortions where the procedure is legal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Working on a Sri Lankan-Australian Epic, He Learned His Family’s Past
description: As the acclaimed “Counting and Cracking” makes its North American debut, the playwright describes the work as “my soul on a plate.”
content: The playwright S. Shakthidharan has lived in Australia since he was a toddler, but when he speaks of his homeland, he means Sri Lanka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: For Him, a ‘Lion King’ Prequel Is the ‘Most Different Thing I Could Do’
description: Barry Jenkins broke out as a filmmaker with the Oscar-winning indie film “Moonlight.” He has surprised some of his fans by taking up a Disney franchise.
content: By his own rough count, the filmmaker Barry Jenkins has seen the 1994 animated movie “The Lion King” around 155 times, many of those viewings with two young nephews and a well-worn VHS tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How a Celebrity Hairstylist Spends His Sundays
description: Jerome Lordet grabs a scooter to get around the city and make house calls for his famous clients.
content: Jerome Lordet made his way to New York from his native Paris as a teenager in 1983 after training with Frédéric Fekkai and other French hair luminaries. He became a fixture at the swanky Pierre Michel Salon on the Upper East Side for more than a quarter century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘Grounded’: How a New Opera Changed on Its Way to the Met
description: Jeanine Tesori and George Brant discuss the first time they heard “Grounded,” and how they instantly knew what they would change for the Met.
content: Allow the creators of opera some grace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Salmonella Outbreak Prompts Egg Recall by Wisconsin Farm
description: Officials said 65 people in nine states have been infected in the outbreak, which has been traced to an egg farm. No deaths have been reported.
content: A salmonella outbreak that has sickened dozens of people in nine states prompted a recall of certain brands of eggs on Friday after officials said they traced the source of the infections to a farm in Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Can ‘The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives’ Change a Conservative Religious Culture?
description: A seemingly frothy reality show has a deeper conflict at its core.
content: In the seventh episode of the new reality show “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives,” a character makes this observation of a fellow married mom struggling with a controlling husband: “It’s kind of a theme with our church, though, and kind of what the problem is. Everyone is getting married before their brains even develop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak and Federico Rios
title: They’re Sizing Up Earth’s Lungs. It Takes Tape Measures and Tree Climbing.
description: A small team in a remote corner of Colombia is surveying every tree in an effort to better understand how much planet-warming carbon the Amazon actually stores.
content: With the help of a small rope tied around his ankles, Eugenio Sánchez, lithe at age 50, shimmied himself all the way up a towering tree like a human inchworm, his chest heaving from the exertion, just to pick a few leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Ephrat Livni
title: Family of American Slain in the West Bank Demands an Independent Inquiry
description: With witnesses and Palestinian officials accusing Israeli soldiers of firing the fatal shots, “an Israeli investigation is not adequate,” the family said in a statement.
content: The family of an American woman killed at a protest in the occupied West Bank demanded an independent investigation on Saturday, saying that Israel could not investigate her death impartially because witnesses and Palestinian officials accused Israeli soldiers of killing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Can Ban Guns in Parks and Bars, but Not Hospitals, Court Says
description: California and Hawaii banned guns from various public venues. A federal appeals court dusted off the history books to help determine where to allow prohibitions.
content: A federal appeals court on Friday partly reinstated firearm bans in California and Hawaii, finding that California could, for example, prohibit guns in parks, playgrounds and bars but not in banks or hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Dozens Fall Ill on Hawaii Hiking Trail in ‘Concerning’ Outbreak of Norovirus
description: Four people tested positive for the virus, which causes a highly contagious gastrointestinal illness, officials said. The trail was recommended to remain closed until at least Sept. 19.
content: A popular hiking trail on the island of Kauai in Hawaii was closed this week after more than three dozen people fell ill in what officials said was a “rare occurrence” of the highly contagious norovirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Harris Releases Ad Targeting Trump for Helping Overturn Roe v. Wade
description: The ad, which will run in several battleground states, comes as a growing share of voters say that abortion is their top issue.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign released a TV advertisement on Saturday reminding voters that former President Donald J. Trump has taken credit for helping overturn Roe v. Wade, and targeting the growing share of voters who say that abortion is their top issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump Urges Police Officers to Watch for Voter Fraud
description: Speaking to the national board of the Fraternal Order of Police, former President Donald J. Trump made an appeal that could run afoul of state laws and prompt accusations of voter intimidation.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump urged the board of the nation’s largest police union on Friday to “watch for voter fraud” across the country, an appeal that, if followed through on, could run afoul of multiple state laws and raise accusations of voter intimidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Missouri Judge Rules That Abortion Ballot Measure Is Invalid
description: But abortion rights groups hope an appeals court will reverse the ruling before the Tuesday deadline to print the state ballots.
content: A Missouri court late Friday moved toward striking a ballot measure in November that would ask voters whether to establish a right to abortion in the state Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar
title: ‘Cow Vigilantes’ Have India’s Muslims on Edge
description: An unexpectedly narrow victory at the polls for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Hindu-first agenda has not cooled simmering sectarian tensions, as some had hoped.
content: A recent series of attacks by Hindus on Muslims in India have highlighted how sectarian violence remains a serious problem, even as the country seeks to define itself on the world stage as a robust democracy with equal rights for all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Starliner’s Troubles Are Latest Setback for Boeing’s Space Business
description: The capsule, which returned without astronauts, and other space programs at Boeing have suffered many delays and cost overruns.
content: Space programs are a small part of Boeing’s business, which is dominated by sales of commercial and military planes and equipment. But the work is a point of pride: Boeing has long been involved in spaceflight, going back to the first mission to take an American to space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: The American Dream Without a House? Believe It
description: As housing costs soar, younger adults are trying to reimagine prosperity — without the white picket fence.
content: “American Dream Properties” is the name of a McMansion developer in New Jersey. About a decade ago, Arlington, Texas, rebranded itself as “The American Dream City,” promising “diverse neighborhoods where the housing dollar stretches further than most cities.” At a campaign rally in York County, Pa., last month, Donald J. Trump said, “We’re going to bring back a thing called the American dream.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Schaitkin
title: Elizabeth Strout Gets the Gang Back Together for a Murder Mystery
description: In “Tell Me Everything,” Bob Burgess deepens his emotional connection with Lucy Barton as he defends a local man accused of killing his mother.
content: Elizabeth Strout’s readers have spent nearly three decades watching her characters’ lives intersect across her body of work. Her 10th book, the tender “Tell Me Everything,” has the feel of a long-awaited reunion: Olive Kitteridge, Lucy Barton, the Burgess siblings, William and Margaret and Helen and Pam — the gang’s all here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Life Milestones
description: Meghan Morris’s Sunday puzzle asks us to save the date(s).
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Bernhard Warner and Ravi Mattu
title: Can the Business of Tennis Be Fixed?
description: In an interview with DealBook, the U.S.T.A. chief Lew Sherr discussed the U.S. Open’s record attendance, the prospect of a new tennis league, and fighting with pickleball for court space.
content: This weekend, Jessica Pegula and Aryna Sabalenka, and then Jannik Sinner and Taylor Fritz, will face off in championship matches as the U.S. Open concludes what has been a booming 144th run. The tournament is expected to draw more than a million in fans for the first time, sell $10 million worth of Honey Deuce cocktails and offer up its biggest prize pool ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The U.S. Open Concludes
description: Let us consider the grief of the lapsed sports fan.
content: “It’s like Black Friday at Walmart,” a tennis fan told The Times of the record-breaking attendance at this year’s U.S. Open. This sort of review might make a normal person glad they’d opted out of attending the tournament. But the more I heard of the colossal throngs, the endless lines attendees were enduring to procure a souvenir hat or a Honey Deuce or just to get inside the stadium complex, the more I wished I were there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Mushroom-Laced Candy Recall Highlights F.D.A.’s Limited Safety Role
description: More than 150 people were sickened from products sold at smoke and vape shops, providing evidence of the lax regulation of new food items.
content: Nearly 160 people have reportedly been sickened this summer by eating mushroom-laced candy and chocolate bars that are widely available at vape and smoke shops, underscoring the dangers of a sprawling market of psychoactive products that pop up on store shelves with no review or regulation across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Hua
title: The Great American Family Car Ride
description: Three bridges, one toll.
content: In the early 1980s, whenever we piled into the family sedan, my siblings and I would jostle one another for space in the back seat. If one of us extended a millimeter of thigh or shoulder beyond our allotment, accusations would fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: None of Trump’s Economic ‘Solutions’ Hold Any Water
description: Trump has only two answers to every problem: tariffs and mass deportation.
content: Ask Donald Trump what he’ll do about any of the nation’s economic problems and he’ll give you one of three answers. He’ll either promise to cut taxes, raise tariffs or deport millions of people. When asked about child care, for example, Trump told the Economic Club of New York that he would raise “trillions” of dollars from new tariffs on virtually every good imported into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Richard Fausset
title: Heritage Foundation Spreads Deceptive Videos About Noncitizen Voters
description: The right-wing think tank has been pushing misinformation about voting into social media feeds. The Georgia secretary of state’s office called one video “a stunt.”
content: In July, two men went door to door at a sprawling apartment complex in Norcross, Ga., an Atlanta suburb that is a hub for the region’s fast-growing Latino population, asking residents if they were U.S. citizens and whether they were registered to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malika Khurana, Kalina Borkiewicz, Elena Shao, Bora Erden, Ashley Wu and Bedel Saget
title: Trump Claims Harris’s Rallies Are Smaller. We Counted.
description: We took photographs, captured 360-degree video and counted attendees at six recent rallies to analyze which of the candidates’ claims on crowd sizes hold weight.
content: We took photographs, captured 360-degree video and counted attendees at six recent rallies to analyze which of the candidates’ claims on crowd sizes hold weight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and AFP
title: Typhoon Yagi Lashes Vietnam With Strong Winds and Torrential Rain
description: At least four people have died and thousands have been evacuated after Typhoon Yagi, one of the strongest storms to hit northern Vietnam, made landfall.
content: At least four people have died and thousands have been evacuated after Typhoon Yagi, one of the strongest storms to hit northern Vietnam, made landfall.
source.name: The New York Times
